Catalytic combustion of lean methane is an effective measure to alleviate the greenhouse effect, which posing extensive demands for catalysts with appreciable reactivity and thermal stability. Herein, the reactivity and thermal stability of Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by ammonia evaporation and impregnation were tested. Experimental results indicated that the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method exhibited higher catalytic activity than that prepared by the impregnation method with similar Pd loadings. Especially, when the palladium loading is 0.1 %, the methane conversion of Pd/ZSM-5 prepared by AE method maintained at 80 % for 12 h at 550 °C while the methane conversion of Pd/ZSM-5 prepared by IM method decreased from 70 % to 20 % within 12 h at 550 °C. Through characterization, it was found that the elevated reactivity originated from the high dispersion of palladium due to the boosted interaction between palladium species and ZSM-5 support. These findings on the preparation of Pd catalysts via ammonia evaporation offer a practical reference for catalyst preparation environment adjustment, active species anchoring, and support-metal interactions, thus providing a promising blueprint for the design of future methane catalytic combustion materials. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lean methane Catalytic combustion Palladium-based catalysts Ammonia evaporation method Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Owing to the lowest CH ratio among all hydrocarbons, the development and utilization of methane (CH4) is regarded as a bridge to shift the overall energy structure towards renewable energy. CH4 has great potentials in the field of power generation, transportation energy source, and chemical raw materials. Furthermore, methane is the main component of natural gas, coal bed methane (CBM) and biological fermentation gas, with rich reserves and high calorific value. However, unburned CH4 inevitably exists in the exhaust gas and low-concentration methane emissions occur in the extraction process of aforementioned gas sources. On top of that, CH4 has a much severe greenhouse effect compared to carbon dioxide (CO2), thus those leaked lean methane (CH4 concentration < 5 %) will exacerbate air pollution. Thus, the treatment of lean methane in exhaust gases has attracted extensive research, among which, catalytic combustion technology, which directly converts CH4 to CO2, holds pivotal significance in addressing this issue and represents an effective approach to achieving the harmonious development of efficient CH4 utilization and environmental protection [1–6]. Noble metal catalysts have excellent performance in lean methane catalytic combustion. Jiabin Ji et al. prepared PtIr/TiO2 catalyst, which has electron rich Ir species, which is conducive to the adsorption and activation of methane [7].Pt and Au have strong adsorption and activation ability for methane, which is conducive to catalytic combustion of methane [8,9]. Pd-supported catalysts are the most widely used catalysts for methane combustion due to their high catalytic activity [6,10–17]. Jinshu Tian et al. studied the catalytic activity of Pd/CeO2 for methane combustion, and found that the catalyst could completely convert methane to CO2 at 390 °C [18]. Jieying Cai et al. prepared the Pd/15CoAlOx catalyst, and achieved the complete oxidation of methane at 400 °C [19]. K Murata et al. investigated the influence of palladium particle size on the methane catalytic combustion activity of Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, and found that only the appropriate palladium particle size (5–7 nm) could promote the reaction [20–22]. Yuanlong Tian et al. controlled the interaction between palladium and CeO2 by adjusting the loading amount of palladium, which enhanced the catalytic combustion activity of lean methane [23]. It is logically concluded that the appropriate palladium particle size significantly affects catalyst activity. By selecting suitable support materials for palladium species, their dispersion could be greatly enhanced. Among a variety of supports with large specific surface area, pore structure and ability to anchor active metals (e.g., metal oxide nanosheet/nanotube, metal organic framework materials), zeolite supports are appealing. This is because zeolite has excellent stability, uniform pore structure, and low synthesis cost [24,25]. Inhak Song et al. prepared a palladium-loaded catalyst in the micropores of FER zeolite, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance for CO oxidation [26]. Additionally, they found that palladium can also be loaded into the micropores of SSZ-13 [27]. Considering the relationship between the size of substrate molecules such as CH4 and the confinement effect of zeolite pores, ZSM-5, as a microporous zeolite with strong adsorption capacity for methane, is viewed as a suitable support for palladium species to achieve the catalytic combustion of lean CH4 [28–30]. Moreover, microporous materials have shown excellent performance in the field of methane to methanol production [31]. However, Pd clusters or nano particles still has the disadvantage of sintering after continuous use which would limit their industrial applications. Therefore, it is noteworthy to seek modification methods to improve the stability of palladium species over zeolite support. Enhancing the interaction between the metal and the support can better anchor the metal on the support, which is an effective mean to improve the stability of the catalyst [32–34]. Jifeng Pang et al. employed a novel method, namely ammonia evaporation, to prepare Cu-MFI catalyst [35]. They found that the alkaline environment benefitted the formation of Cu-O-Si configuration, thereby stabilizing the form of Cu+ leading to high performance and unprecedented stability. Our laboratory has also achieved significant progress in the preparation of catalysts using the AE method [36,37]. In a series of exploratory experiments, palladium was supported on ZSM-5 using both the AE method and the IM method. We observed significant differences in catalyst performance between these two preparation methods (when the palladium loading was 1 %, the T90 of the catalyst prepared by AE method was 368 °C, whereas the T90 of the catalyst prepared by IM method was only 392 °C). In this work, we conducted a series of experiments and characterizations to investigate the underlying reasons. TEM, XPS, in situ DRIFT and other characterization methods indicated that the high activity of the catalyst prepared by AE method was due to the electron-rich palladium species and the high dispersion of Pd species while the thermal stability was due to the strong Pd-support interaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of ZSM-5-Supported palladium catalysts 2.1.1 Ammonia evaporation method Firstly, 0.5 g of ZSM-5 support was added to 25 mL of deionized water. Then ammonia solution was added to the deionized water with a recommended pH of 12.0. Once the pH reached 12.0, the container was sealed by Parafilm and the solution was stirred for ten minutes. Then 0.5 mL of Pd(NO3)2 aqueous solution (with a Pd content of 1 mg/mL) was added. And continue stirring the precursor solution of palladium under sealed conditions for 1 hour to complete the ion exchange. Finally, Parafilm was removed. and the solution was stirred at 90 °C for 1 hour to complete the evaporation process. Solid precipitate was obtained by centrifugation and washing with deionized water three times. the precipitate was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and grinded to obtain a powdered sample. Then the precipitate was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h. The catalyst was named 0.1Pd/ZSM-5, where 0.1 represents a theoretical loading of 0.1 %. The catalysts with different loadings were prepared and named in the same way. 2.1.2 Wetness impregnation method Firstly, 0.5 g of ZSM-5 zeolite was added to 25 mL of deionized water, followed by 0.5 mL of Pd(NO3)2 aqueous solution (with a Pd content of 1mg/mL). Stir the precursor solution of palladium for 12 h and aging for 2 h. Solid precipitate was obtained by centrifugation and washing with deionized water three times. The precipitate was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and grinded to obtain a powdered sample. The catalyst was obtained by calcining the sample at 400 °C for 2 h. The catalyst was named 0.1Pd/H-ZSM-5-IM, where 0.1 represents a theoretical loading of 0.1 %. The catalysts with different loadings were prepared and named in the same way. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Samples’ X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a Rigaku TTR-III diffractor using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 200 mA). The diffraction spectra were recorded in the 2θ range of 5° to 80° with a scanning step of 0.02° Transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F instrument) were performed to depict the morphology of selected samples. The STEM EDS elemental mapping of 0.1Pd/H-ZSM-5 and 0.1Pd/H-ZSM-5-Recycled catalysts were also obtained by JEM-2100F that coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Nitrogen-physisorption was operated at ∼77 K on a Quantachrome Autosorb IQ instrument to get the porosity structures.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was taken on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer system with Al Kα x-ray source (1486.6 eV) at ultrahigh vacuum. The XPS spectra were deconvoluted with the Avantage software and calibrated against the C1s line (284.8 eV) originating from adventitious carbon.H2-TPR experiments were performed on Quantachrome TPRWin v3.52. The catalyst was first purged at Ar atmosphere for 30 min at 200 °C before adsorbing 10 %H2/Ar mixture gas (25 mL/min) at 50 °C. Unabsorbed H2 was removed by Ar flow, and the samples were finally heated to 800 °C at 5 °C /min. The signals caused by H2 consumption were detected by TCD detectors. O2-TPD experiments were performed on Microtrac BELCat II. The catalyst was first purged at He atmosphere for 30 mins at 200 °C before adsorbing 10 % O2/He mixture gas (30 mL/min) at 50 °C. The weakly physically adsorbed O2 on the surface was removed by blowing with He, and the samples were finally heated to 800 °C at 10 °C /min. The signals were detected by TCD detectors. The TGA experiments of the precursors of palladium catalysts were conducted on the PerkinElmer STA 6000 from room temperature to 600 °C at N2 atmosphere. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectra (DRIFTS) was recorded on a Niolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector and a customized reaction chamber. The catalysts of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 and 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM were first placed in the reaction chamber and pretreated with argon at room temperature for 0.5 h. After the collection of background, DRIFT spectra were recorded at ramped temperatures under 1.0 % CH4/air mixture gas flow to simulate the reaction process. The spectrum of each catalyst sample at a particular temperature was the accumulation of 64 scans with a resolution of 4 cm-1. The catalytic combustion of lean methane was conducted in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with an internal diameter of 8.0 mm at ambient pressure. Typically, 20 mg of catalyst was fixed by S3quartz glass wool while the reactants (1 vol % CH4 balanced with air) was fed through the sample via a mass flow controller. The flow rate of reactant gas was maintained at 20 standard state cubic centimeter per minute (SCCM), which corresponded to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 mL·g-1·h-1. The conversion of CH4 and the selectivity of CO2 were calculated by the peak area changes of CH4 and CO2. The CO2 selectivity of all catalysts exceeds 95 %, demonstrating their superiority in methane catalytic combustion. Considering that there is an excess of oxygen in the reaction gas and only peaks of CH4 and CO2 are detected in the signal, we believe that methane is completely converted to CO2. Dissolve palladium completely using microwave digestion and measure the actual loading amount of palladium using ICP-OES. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalysts performance 3.1.1 Catalytic activity of Pd/ZSM-5 and Pd/ZSM-5-IM with different palladium loadings The catalytic activity of catalysts with varying Pd loadings was tested on a fixed-bed reactor, and the corresponding results are presented in Fig. 1 . Additionally, the T50 and T90 values were summarized in Table 1 . As observed in Fig. 1a, when the palladium loading is relatively low, specifically 0.1 %, the catalyst prepared via impregnation method exhibits significantly higher activity compared to the catalyst prepared using the ammonia evaporation method. However, it is noteworthy that at temperatures exceeding 500 °C, the catalytic activity of the 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM catalyst begins to decline, whereas the methane conversion rate of the 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst remains in an upward trend. This indicates that the catalyst prepared via impregnation method has relatively poor stability. When the loading is higher, the IM samples demonstrate lower activity compared to the catalyst prepared using the ammonia evaporation method. Specifically, the T90 value for the 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst is 368 °C, whereas the T90 value for the 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM catalyst is 392 °C. Further experiments on catalysts with Pd loading ranging from 0.1 % to 1.0 % were demonstrated in Fig. 1b At Pd loading of 0.3 % to 0.5 %, all AE samples showed similar lean methane combustion ability to IM samples. The specific T90 data is presented in Table 1. Yet when the Pd loading is further increased to 0.7 %, the T90 for 0.7Pd/ZSM-5 is 408 °C, while for 0.7Pd/ZSM-5-IM, it is 438 °C. An obverse decrease in T90 was achieved over AE sample. Notably, the catalytic activity of 0.7Pd/ZSM-5 is stronger than that of 0.5Pd/ZSM-5, while the catalytic activity of 0.7Pd/ZSM-5-IM is weaker than that of 0.5Pd/ZSM-5-IM. This indicates that as the palladium loading increases, changes detrimental to catalytic activity occur in the catalyst prepared by impregnation, whereas this reduction in activity does not occur in the process of ammonia evaporation. To elucidate the underlying reasons, further studies were conducted on catalysts with palladium loadings of 0.1 %, 0.7 %, and 1.0 %. 3.1.2 Thermal stability of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 and 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM In light of the performance of 0.1 Pd/ZSM-5-IM under high-temperature conditions depicted in Fig. 1a, further tests on the thermal stability of Pd/ZSM-5 and Pd/ZSM-5-IM were conducted at 550 °C. The pertinent results are exhibited in Fig. 2 . Evidently, at this relatively high temperature, the methane conversion rate of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM declined precipitously, plummeting from 70 % to 30 % within 4 h, followed by a gradual decrease and eventual stabilization at approximately 20 %. This phenomenon may be attributed to the deactivation of the catalyst due to the agglomeration of Pd under high-temperature conditions. Conversely, the methane conversion rate of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 remained unaltered throughout the test. In addition, the catalysts prepared by AE method showed good thermal stability, while the activity of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM decreased by 5 % after 12 h. This suggests that the catalyst prepared via the ammonia evaporation method may circumvent the agglomeration of Pd. 3.2 Dispersion states of palladium species To elucidate the origin of these lean methane combustion reactivity trend and the exceptional stability of the AE samples, an in-depth investigation into the structure-activity relationship of the catalyst was conducted, involving detailed characterization of the catalyst surface features and the distribution of Pd species. Pd particles appeared on 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM, indicating that even at extremely low concentration, Pd species would still tend to cluster during impregnation process. This is because during the preparation process, some of the silicon in the 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst was removed, which resulted in the formation of Si defect sites that could specifically anchoring the introduced Pd2+ precursors. However, during the preparation process of the 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM catalyst, there was no desilication, so palladium would aggregate on the outer surface of ZSM-5 support and eventually block its channels. As evidenced by Table 2 , it can be observed that the pore volume of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 is 0.044 cm3/g, which is greater than the pore volume of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM (0.038 cm3/g). It is remarkable that the pore volume of 0.7Pd/ZSM-5 is 0.039 cm3/g, which is almost the same as that of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM. This indicated that the degree of blockage of the pores by palladium in 0.7Pd/ZSM-5 is comparable to that in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM. And the pore volume of 0.7Pd/ZSM-5-IM is 0.030 cm3/g, further deepening the degree of blockage. Moreover, as the palladium loading increased, the size of Pd particles on the catalyst also increased. When the palladium loading increased from 0.7 % to 1.0 %, the average particle size of Pd particles on the catalyst prepared by ammonia evaporation method increased from 2.72 nm to 3.03 nm. This is because as the load increased, palladium gradually grows into larger nanoparticles. while the average particle size of Pd particles on the catalyst prepared by impregnation method increased from 3.13 nm to 4.18 nm suggesting that without the assistance of Si vacancy, the agglomeration will be intensely aggravated. This proved that the ammonia evaporation method has an excellent effect on promoting the dispersion of palladium nanoparticles. Smaller palladium nanoparticles also provide more active sites for the complete oxidation of methane. 3.3 X-ray diffraction analysis and ICP-OES elemental analysis Fig. 4 showed the XRD spectra of all Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts. The results showed that the XRD spectra of all Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts were similar to H-ZSM-5 zeolite [38,39]. This indicates that neither of the two preparation methods has disrupted the crystal structure of ZSM-5. It is noteworthy that no peak related to palladium was detected on the XRD spectrum. Moreover, considering that 33.8° and 40° are the peak regions of PdO and Pd species, we had enlarged the XRD pattern regions in this range, but no peak of Pd species has been observed yet. Considering that the highest loading amount of palladium is only 1.0 %, and the particle size of the obtained palladium nanoparticles is not high, it was reasonable that the XRD spectrum could not detect the palladium signal. Next, we will analyze the valence state of palladium through further characterization. Additionally, considering that centrifugation and washing steps inevitably lead to the loss of some Pd species, and altering the pH value can affect the loading amount, we explored the actual Pd loading in the catalyst using ICP-OES. The results were presented in Table 3 . The findings indicated that during the preparation process of both methods, a portion of palladium is lost. However, the actual loading amounts of catalysts prepared by the two methods are not significantly different. Therefore, it is reasonable to characterize and compare catalysts with the same theoretical Pd loading amount in this article. 3.4 Dispersion states of palladium species in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-Recycled and 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM-Recycled Considering the difference in thermal stability of catalysts with a palladium loading of 0.1 %, we recovered and characterized the catalyst after 12 h of reaction at 550 °C. The result was shown in Fig. 5. The image of the fresh catalyst has already been presented in Fig. 3 . There are still no visible palladium particles on the 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-Recycled catalyst, and Pd species remained dispersed. As anticipated palladium particle clusters were formed on the 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM-Recycled catalyst. This further indicates that Pd is loaded inside the defect sites in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5. When the loading amount of palladium increased, and the palladium nanoparticles began to form on the support, defect sites made the interaction between ZSM-5 support and Pd species stronger, and Pd will not escape and agglomerate. The pore structure prevented the agglomeration of palladium at high temperature, thereby ensuring thermal stability. And the Pd in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM is loaded on the surface of the support. Therefore, under high temperature conditions, the palladium species on 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM agglomerated to form larger particles, resulting in catalyst deactivation. 3.5 Defect and metal-support interaction analysis In Fig. 6 a, When the palladium loading was 0.1 %, a slight deviation in the binding energy of Pd in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM was observed. This may be because 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM had the tendency to form clusters compared with 0.1Pd/ZSM-5. The high binding energy of palladium in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 also indicated that palladium was filled into the defect sites formed by desilication. When the palladium loading reached 0.7 %, the binding energy of 0.7Pd/ZSM-5 experiences a slight downward offset (−0.02 eV). This can be attributed to the fact that palladium gains more electrons on the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method. When the palladium loading reaches 1.0 %, the shift in binding energy of Pd in 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 was greater (−0.08 eV). This indicated that with an increase in palladium loading, the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method gains more electrons relative to the catalyst prepared by impregnation. Fig. 6c shows the change in binding energy of Si. It can be observed from Fig. 6c that with an increase in palladium loading, the binding energy of Si on the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method gradually shifted upward, while there is no significant change in the catalyst prepared by impregnation. This suggested that the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method has a stronger Pd-Si interaction relative to the impregnation method, leading to the transfer of electrons from Si to Pd. To further investigate the valence state changes of Pd, their Pd 3d spectra were deconvoluted and were shown in Fig. 6c. When the palladium loading was 0.1 %, even though there were indications of clusters in 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM, due to the extremely low loading, XPS only exhibited peaks corresponding to Pd2+. However, at higher palladium loadings, the palladium phase in the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method was predominantly Pdδ+(336.72 eV, 0<δ<2), while in the catalyst prepared by impregnation, the palladium phase was predominantly Pd2+(337.20 eV) [38,40–42]. Comparing the peak curves around a binding energy of approximately 335.0 eV, it can also be observed that the catalyst prepared by ammonia evaporation exhibits a minor peak at this location, whereas the catalyst prepared by impregnation shows no peak, indicating that the catalyst prepared by ammonia evaporation had more Pd0 species. The aforementioned results demonstrate that, relative to Pd/ZSM-5-IM, the Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited a stronger Pd-Si interaction. At the same time, the Si/Al ratio of the catalyst is given in Table 3. Compared with Pd/ZSM-5-IM, Pd/ZSM-5 has a lower Si/Al ratio, indicating that mild desilication occurred in catalysts prepared via the ammonia evaporation method. The defects formed after silicon leaching provide embedded anchoring sites for Pd, forming a Pd-O-Si structure, resulting in stronger metal-support interactions and ultimately achieving higher stability. 3.6 Redox properties of palladium catalysts As Fig. 7 a showed, there was no significant difference in the H2-TPR data between 0.1Pd/ZSM-5 and 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM. This should be attributed to the low loading of palladium. Fig. 7b, c showed the H2-TPR data of catalysts with palladium loadings of 0.7 % and 1.0 %. It can be observed that negative peaks appear in the H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts at low temperatures. These peaks can be attributed to the decomposition of PdHx species, proving the introduction of palladium species [38,43]. However, the decomposition temperatures of PdHx for the two catalysts are different. The decomposition temperature of PdHx on 0.7Pd/ZSM-5 is 82 °C, while that on 1.0 Pd/ZSM-5 is 87 °C. The decomposition temperature of PdHx on 0.7 Pd/ZSM-5 and 1.0 Pd/ZSM-5-IM is 79 °C. The reduction temperature of PdHx on Pd/ZSM-5 is higher than that on Pd/ZSM-5-IM. This indicated that the palladium species on the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method is more stable, making it harder to be reduced. This result is in good agreement with the above phenomenon of the stronger interaction between palladium and the support in the Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst. In addition, all catalysts exhibit negative peak signals at 200–300 °C. The signal at this point was likely to originate from H2 adsorbed by ZSM-5. The TPR profile of 1.0 Pd/ZSM-5 exhibited a clear signal at around 360 °C. Considering the low reduction temperature of precious metals, the signal here should be the reduction of silicon-related species [44]. The H2 consumption of the sample at lower temperatures indicated that it was more reducible, meaning it lacked electrons. This indicated that with the palladium loading increased, the interaction between palladium and support become stronger due to the Si-O-Pd structure, and more electrons were transferred from silicon to palladium, which made the catalyst easier to be reduced. This result was also consistent with the results obtained from XPS. O2-TPD was further employed. Signals at 200–400 °C can be attributed to the desorption of active oxygen on the surface, while signals above 500 °C can be considered as lattice oxygen [45,46]. It can be seen from Fig. 7d, the desorption temperature of active oxygen on the surface for 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 is around 400 °C, whereas for 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM, it is at 450 °C. Therefore, the catalytic activity of active oxygen on the surface in 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 is stronger than that in 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM. Furthermore, based on the calculation of O2-TPD peak area, the oxygen desorption amount for 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 is greater than that for 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM. This indicated that 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 had a stronger adsorption capacity for oxygen. These results demonstrate that the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method exhibits stronger adsorption and activation capabilities for oxygen. 3.7 Hydroxyl state on the catalyst surface The thermogravimetric test results of the dried catalyst under a nitrogen atmosphere are presented in Fig. 8 a. Considering that nitrogen rarely reacts with the catalyst and the catalyst has been subjected to dehydration treatment, the weight loss measured by TGA should mainly come from the removal of surface hydroxyl groups. As can be seen from Fig. 8a, the weight loss of the catalyst mainly occurred before 200 °C, which should be due to the removal of Si-OH or Al-OH. The weight loss curves of catalysts prepared by the ammonia evaporation method showed little difference. However, the weight loss curve of catalysts prepared by impregnation is related to the loading amount of Pd. As the palladium content increases, palladium gradually forms clusters, which may occupy the positions of surface hydroxyl groups. In addition, all Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts have more surface hydroxyl groups than Pd/ZSM-5-IM. To further explore the properties of surface hydroxyl groups, NH3-TPD characterization was conducted on 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 and 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM. The signal at 100 °C-250 °C in Fig. 8b should be attributed to Lewis acid sites (Al-OH), while the signal at 450 °C should be attributed to Bronsted acid sites (Si-OH-Al) [47–49]. Compared to 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM, 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 possesses more weak acid sites and almost the same strong acid sites. Rich Lewis acid can enhance the interaction between the support and palladium, thus ensuring the high dispersion of palladium [50]. However, this still cannot explain why the weight loss of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 is much greater than that of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM. Therefore, some hydroxyl groups on 1.0 Pd/ZSM-5 are Si-OH. Based on the above results, we propose that mild desilication has two effects on the catalyst: the removal of silicon on Si-O-Si, which lead to the formation of Si-OH and defect sites on the catalyst; the removal of silicon on Si-O-Al, which lead to the formation of Al-OH on the catalyst. The former facilitated the loading and dispersion of Pd on the pores, while the latter contributed to the formation of Lewis acid sites. The corresponding mechanism of desilication by ammonia evaporation method has also been proposed: At low temperature, NH3 forms a [Pd(NH3)4]2+ complex with Pd to prevent premature precipitation of Pd. At the same time, under alkaline conditions, Si-O-Si begins to fracture, forming defect sites(Si-OH). The defect sites are negatively charged, while the [Pd(NH3)4]2+complexes are positively charged, which facilitates their binding. During the evaporation process, ammonia begins to evaporate, the [Pd(NH3)4]2+ complex begins to decompose, and palladium is uniformly loaded on the defect sites formed by desilication. 3.8 Reaction mechanism of methane combustion The reaction pathway of methane combustion was explored via in-situ DRIFT as shown in Fig. 9 . Methane can react with Pd active sites to form salt-like substances, which are then further oxidized by active oxygen into carbonates. The signal at 3015 cm-1 corresponded to the vibrational peak of gaseous methane (*CH4), the signal at 1585 cm-1 come from the asymmetric stretching vibration of formic acid (*HCOOH), and the signal at 1643 cm-1 corresponded to bidentate carbonates [51,52]. Notably, the signal at 3015 cm-1 gradually decreased as temperature rises, indicating the consumption of *CH4. At 150 °C, there was a clear peak at 1585 cm-1, while no obvious signal at 1643 cm-1 could be seen. This indicated that formate species were formed at even lower temperatures. As the temperature increased, the signal for *HCOOH gradually decreased, while the signal at 1643 cm-1 gradually increased which proved the conversion of formate species into carbonates. However, the signals at 1585 cm-1 and 1643 cm-1 on 1.0 Pd/ZSM-5-IM are relatively weak. Also it is noticed that there are significant differences in the peaks at 3600–3800 cm-1 (corresponding to hydroxyl groups, e.g., *H2O, Al-OH, Si-OH) between the two catalysts [53]. At 150 °C, 1.0 Pd/ZSM-5 has a relatively obvious hydroxyl peak, while the hydroxyl peak signal on 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM is weaker. Considering the low reaction temperature, the hydroxyl groups here should come from the catalyst, which is consistent with the previous TGA results (Fig. 8a). As the temperature increased, the hydroxyl signals of both 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 and 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM gradually increased, but the hydroxyl signal of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 is always stronger than that of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM. The reaction of CH4 on Pd sites to generate hydroxyl groups resulted in an enhancement of hydroxyl signal [54]. The relevant results of in-situ DRIFT provide the overall conversion pathway of methane. Methane is first activated at the Pd site, generating formate species. Then, the formate reacted with active oxygen to produce carbonate, which is finally converted into carbon dioxide. Due to the more electron-rich Pd sites on 1.0Pd/ZSM-5, methane is more easily activated; and the higher number of hydroxyl groups on 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 also promotes the generation of active oxygen, thereby facilitating the reaction. The cooperation between Pd sites and acid sites is conducive to catalytic activity, providing a reasonable explanation for the strong catalytic performance of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5. Considering the results from XPS, we believed that the active site of the reaction was PdOx. The electron-rich Pd0 species on PdOx can adsorb and activate methane, while the Pd2+ species on PdOx can adsorb oxygen. The synergistic interaction between these two different Pd species facilitated the reaction. 4 Conclusion In summary, we demonstrated a new method for synthesizing Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst using ammonia evaporation method, demonstrating its excellent performance and thermal stability in methane oxidation reaction. The high dispersion of palladium and stable activity under high temperature conditions were achieved on 0.1Pd/ZSM-5, while although the catalytic performance of 0.1Pd/ZSM-5-IM is better, palladium will sinter into large particles at high temperatures. The catalytic performance of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5 (T90=368 °C) is stronger than that of 1.0Pd/ZSM-5-IM (T90=392 °C). This method achieved mild desilication without affecting the ZSM-5 structure, which had three impacts on the catalyst. 1) The ammonia evaporation method can produce defect sites on the surface of the support and better anchor palladium species; 2) The ammonia evaporation method enhances the Pd-O-Si interaction, making palladium more difficult to aggregate, also providing electron rich Pd species that contribute to methane activation; 3) The ammonia evaporation method increases the acid sites of the catalyst, which is beneficial for the high dispersion of palladium. These findings on ammonia-evaporated Pd catalysts provide practical insights for catalyst preparation, active species anchoring, and support-metal interactions, offering a promising blueprint for future methane combustion materials. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic combustion of lean methane is an effective measure to alleviate the greenhouse effect, which posing extensive demands for catalysts with appreciable reactivity and thermal stability. Herein, the reactivity and thermal stability of Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts prepared by ammonia evaporation and impregnation were tested. Experimental results indicated that the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method exhibited higher catalytic activity than that prepared by the impregnation method with similar Pd loadings. Especially, when the palladium loading is 0.1 %, the methane conversion of Pd/ZSM-5 prepared by AE method maintained at 80 % for 12 h at 550 °C while the methane conversion of Pd/ZSM-5 prepared by IM method decreased from 70 % to 20 % within 12 h at 550 °C. Through characterization, it was found that the elevated reactivity originated from the high dispersion of palladium due to the boosted interaction between palladium species and ZSM-5 support. These findings on the preparation of Pd catalysts via ammonia evaporation offer a practical reference for catalyst preparation environment adjustment, active species anchoring, and support-metal interactions, thus providing a promising blueprint for the design of future methane catalytic combustion materials.
